conclusion: To determine the magnitude and direction of the current \( I_1 \) in the conductor rod \( cd \), we need to consider the forces acting on the rod and the magnetic field.
The rod is suspended by two strings, with the tension in each string being zero.
The gravitational force \( mg \) acts downward.
The magnetic force \( B_1 I_1 L \) acts upward, where \( B_1 \) is the magnetic induction intensity and \( I_1 \) is the current in the conductor.
The magnetic force \( F \) is given by \( F = B_1 I_1 L \).
The length of the conductor \( L \) is \( 50 \, \text{cm} = 0.5 \, \text{m} \).
The current \( I_1 \) is the same for both strings, so \( I_1 = \frac{F}{B_1 L} \).
The magnetic force \( F \) is equal to the weight of the conductor \( mg \).
Substituting the values, we get \( mg = B_1 I_1 L \).
Rearranging the equation to solve for \( I_1 \), we get \( I_1 = \frac{mg}{B_1 L} \).
Plugging in the values, we get \( I_1 = \frac{0.01 \, \text{kg} \times 10 \, \text{m/s}^2}{1.0 \, \text{T} \times 0.5 \, \text{m}} = 0.2 \, \text{A} \).
The current \( I_1 \) is in the direction of the magnetic force \( B_1 I_1 L \).
Since the magnetic force is upward, the current \( I_1 \) must be in the upward direction.
The magnitude of the current \( I_1 \) in the conductor rod \( cd \) is \( 0.2 \, \text{A} \), and it is directed upward.
